thread.title: Scott Walker's finance reports to provide insight into failed campaign
thread.title_full: Scott Walker's finance reports to provide insight into failed campaign

title: Scott Walker's finance reports to provide insight into failed campaign
text:
(0) Comments 
Madison â€” With fundraising reports due Thursday for presidential campaigns, Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker is expected to lay bare the financial challenges that ended his White House bid last month. 
The report will represent the first look at what Walker's presidential campaign actually raised and spent during the 71 days the Republican governor was an official candidate for the nation's highest office. Walker dropped out of the race on Sept. 21, unable to sustain financially a candidacy that had soared early, raised and spent money aggressively and then faced plummeting polling and donations. 
One key question will be how much debt to consultants and vendors, if any, Walker's campaign has left on the books. 
For his part, Walker told conservative talk radio host Charlie Sykes Wednesday that he wouldn't focus on the mistakes, whether his own or those of his campaign staff. 
"There were a lot of different factors, obviously different candidates, different situations, different staff. All of those things come. Instead of doing what a lot of candidates do and whine about this, that or whatever, for me I accept it for what it is," Walker told Sykes. 
Earlier this week, Walker said his campaign will report relatively strong fundraising . 
"The reports will be out. The bottom line is as in the past we've raised a lot of resources (though) not as much as some of the other candidates," Walker said.   Jason Stein 
Jason Stein covers the state Capitol and is the author with his colleague Patrick Marley of "More than They Bargained For: Scott Walker, Unions and the Fight for Wisconsin." His work has been recognized by journalism groups such as the American Society of News Editors, the Society of American Business Editors and Writers, and the Association of Capitol Reporters and Editors.
